titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Richard Deming Papers, 1939-1988 and undated RL.11683

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-11-26 10:05:13 -0500.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Richard Deming (1915-1983) was an American crime and non-fiction writer. His papers primarily contain manuscripts by Deming, including short stories, novels, t.v. scripts and screenplays, publisher's pitches, along with plays, an article, poetry, and one letter. Some of the novels are written under the pseudonyms or with coauthors. All manuscripts are typescript, except for an incomplete, handwritten novel. The papers also include incomplete runs of mixed serials, all featuring published writing by Deming. These include scattered or single issues of each title and some duplicates. Items with dates past Deming's death in 1983 feature reprints as well as marketing materials for a novel. The collection also includes poetry and a novel-length manuscript written by Richard Deming's uncle, Rollin Gregg Deming.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into the following series: Writings, Serials, and Rollin Gregg Deming.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Richard Deming (1915-1983) was an American crime and non-fiction writer. Deming was born in Des Moines, Iowa, to Fred Kemp Deming and Eva Pearl (Smyers) Deming. His most common pseudonym was Max Franklin, although there were several others. He received his bachelor's degree from Washington University in St. Louis and a master's degree from the University of Iowa. Deming served in the U.S. Army in the European theater between 1941-1945 and became a captain. He married Ruth DuBois in 1948; the couple had three children.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Richard Deming Papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift of John Betancourt in 2017.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Richard Deming Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Accessions described in this collection guide: 2017-0200

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Richard Deming papers primarily contain manuscripts by Deming, including short stories, novels, t.v. scripts and screenplays, publisher's pitches, along with plays, an article, poetry, and one letter. Some of the novels are written under pseudonyms or are co-authored. All manuscripts are typescript, except for an incomplete, handwritten novel. There are two folders containing research for novels and Deming's master's thesis is present. The papers also include incomplete runs of mixed serials, all featuring published writing by Deming. These include scattered or single issues of each title and some duplicates. Items with dates past Deming's death in 1983 feature reprints as well as marketing materials for a novel. The collection also includes poetry and a novel-length manuscript, The World of Snooze, written by Richard Deming's uncle, Rollin Gregg Deming.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series includes short stories, novels, t.v. scripts and screenplays, publisher's pitches, along with plays, an article, poetry, and one letter. Some of the novels are written under the pseudonyms Franklin W. Dixon, Lee Davis Willoughby, Frank Max or Max Franklin, with romance novels by Jessica or Charlotte Fen. Two novels are written with others, including Richard Laymon and Colleen Chandler, and there is a publisher's pitch written with Don Woodbeck and Craig Glazer. All writings are typescript, except for an incomplete, handwritten manuscript novel. There are two folders containing research for novels, and Deming's master's thesis is present. Items dating past Deming's death in 1983 include a reprint short story and marketing materials for a novel. There is an information folder for Deming located in box 1.

scopecontent.p: Series contains incomplete runs of mixed serials, all featuring writing by Deming. There are scattered or single issues of each title and some duplicates. Issues with dates past Deming's death in 1983 feature reprints.
